ai-ud2.1:1.2_0: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying near Uruvelā at the root of the Mucalinda tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.
ai-ud2.1:1.3_0: Now at that time the Buddha was sitting cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
ai-ud2.1:2.1_0: Just then a great storm blew up out of season, bringing seven days of rain, cold winds, and clouds.
ai-ud2.1:2.2_0: Mucalinda, the dragon king, came out from his abode, encircled the Buddha’s body with seven coils and spread his large hood over his head, thinking,
ai-ud2.1:2.3_0: “May the Buddha not be hot or cold, nor be bothered by flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, or reptiles.”
ai-ud2.1:3.1_0: When seven days had passed, the Buddha emerged from that state of immersion.
ai-ud2.1:3.2_0: When he knew the sky was clear, Mucalinda unwrapped his coils from the Buddha’s body. Hiding his own form, he manifested in the form of a brahmin youth. He stood in front of the Buddha, venerating him with joined palms.
ai-ud2.1:4.1_0: Knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud2.1:5.2_0: For the one who sees the Truth that he has heard.
ai-ud2.1:5.3_0: Kindness for the world is happiness
ai-ud2.1:5.4_0: for one who’d not harm a living creature.
ai-ud2.1:6.1_0: Dispassion for the world is happiness
ai-ud2.1:6.2_0: For the stilling of sensual pleasures,
ai-ud2.1:6.3_0: But dispelling the conceit ʻI am’
ai-ud2.1:6.4_0: This, indeed, is the highest bliss.”
ai-ud2.1:6.5_0: First the first part of the body.
